docs.lead_paragraph: In an appearance before a Congressional committee this week, Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, said he was prepared to break Bayer's patent on the anthrax-fighting drug Cipro and order the medicine from generic manufacturers if Bayer did not drop its price. It was a strong-arm negotiating tactic, and it worked. Bayer agreed to slash the price it charges the government for Cipro, and the Bush administration was able to claim it had gotten a better deal for taxpayers.

headline.main: Reconciling the Demands of War and the Market

docs.abstract: Analysis of difficulties Bush administration faces in reconciling demands of war with its pre-Sept 11 philosophy of small government and reliance on market forces to address economic and social issues; says this administration is under intense pressure to intervene in business decisions, prop up or bail out industries, sponsor new government programs and spend whatever it takes to keep nation secure (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: SCHWARBERG-Craig Frederick. March 27, 1956 - October 18, 2001. Craig Frederick Schwarberg passed away October 18, 2001, after a long illness. Craig was born in Pasadena, California, and raised in Whittier and Tiburon, California. He attended Stanford University, was a member of the Varsity Water Polo team, and graduated in 1978 with a Bachelor of Arts degree in Political Science. Craig worked briefly at Evanston Hospital in Illinois. In 1980, he moved to Abu Dhabi, the United Arab Emirates as an executive for the country's health and hospital program. After returning to the United States, Craig earned his Master of Business Administration degree from the University of Chicago in 1982. He began working in public finance at Shearson Lehman Brothers in San Francisco, and in 1986, moved to New York City to work in the corporate finance area. In 1992, he joined International Insurance Advisors, a private equity fund focused on the insurance industry. He served on many boards of directors, in this country and abroad. Craig moved to Kansas City in 1996, where he became involved in a number of community organizations. He was a committed Cub Master for the Boy Scouts of America. He served as a member of the Board of Directors at the Alliance for Epilepsy Research and also for the Kansas Cancer Institute. He was Chairman of the Board of ReStart, an organization serving the homeless of greater Kansas City. Craig was a mentor with the Helzberg Entrepreneurial Mentoring Program, and served as Vice President of Finance for the National Brain Tumor Foundation, headquartered in California. Craig is survived by his wife, Joann; their children Carter, Guerin, and Laine; his parents Clifford and Katherine Schwarberg of Belvedere, California; his sisters Lynn Lubbock of Tiburon, California and Ann Gaillard of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania; and nieces Jaime and Lindsey Lubbock. A Celebration of Life memorial service was held Friday, October 26th in Prairie Village, Kansas. Any memorial contributions may be made to ReStart, 918 E. 9th Street, Kansas City, Missouri, 64106 or The National Brain Tumor Foundation, 414 13th Street, Oakland, California, 94612.

docs.lead_paragraph: THIS is the moment for high-tech Japanese hot rods at bargain prices. First, Subaru introduced the WRX, a smoking fast, turbocharged version of its all-wheel-drive Impreza compact. Now the Acura division of Honda has come through with the RSX, a muscular front-drive coupe. Better yet, there is a more powerful, better handling variant called the Type-S. The RSX Type-S is a showcase for the performance technology that Honda offers those with Porsche tastes on Pabst budgets. Acura is guessing that the typical buyer will be a thrill-seeking male in his 20's. But at $23,650 loaded -- there are no factory options -- it could serve as spirited transportation for couples or very small families with mortgages to service and health insurance deductibles to pay.

docs.lead_paragraph: CERTAIN that government stimulus and multiple interest rate cuts will put the steel back into stock prices, bullish strategists are advising investors to buy now so that they won't miss the inevitable and imminent turn. Never mind that many of these brokerage-firm carnival barkers have been predicting the end of the bear market since the Federal Reserve began its easing action in January. Typically, stocks do begin to recover well before an impaired economy does. Since 1960, according to statisticians at Standard & Poor's, the stock market has bottomed, on average, seven months after a recession has begun. But averages can be deceiving. While the market bottomed just three months after the 1990 recession started, it took 13 months of recession before stocks started their recovery from the 1980-81 downturn.

headline.main: The Risk Of Not Weighing Risk

docs.abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column on study conducted by Alice Cornish, analyst at Prudential Securities, which forecasts that pretax profits of companies in Standard & Poor's 500-stock index will drop by average 2.5 percent in 2002 because of higher insurance prices; says brokerage firms advising investors to buy stocks now are ignoring such constraints on corporate earnings, which were already in decline and are sure to be stunted further by increased costs associated with security and risk since Sept 11; table (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN technology was king, investors bypassed the value mutual funds managed by Bret W. Stanley of AIM Funds in their rush to load up on the company's growth portfolios ''People had come to believe value investing was dead,'' Mr. Stanley said. Now Mr. Stanley, who favors the Gap and the Kroger supermarket chain, is the man of the hour. ''We've been doing and saying the exact same thing,'' Mr. Stanley said, ''but more recently, people are more attentive.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Indiana regulators have approved the conversion of Anthem Inc., one of the largest Blue Cross and Blue Shield insurers, to a publicly traded company from a mutual insurance company owned by policyholders. Anthem, which has 7.5 million members in eight states, plans to seek approval in a policyholder vote on Monday and to sell shares valued at about $1.4 billion in an initial public offering on Tuesday. The price, to be set Monday afternoon, is expected to be $33 to $37.

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors today accused the former top deputy to Nassau County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta and six others of bribery, fraud and money laundering in a health insurance scheme that cost taxpayers $25 million and netted those charged $12.5 million in illicit fees and payoffs, according to indictments filed here. The sweeping charges -- complete with a six-color chart detailing the circuitous flow of money between 13 people and companies -- came at a politically inopportune moment for Nassau County's Republican Party, less than two weeks before the election. In a grueling contest for control of Nassau's government, the Republicans are struggling to hang on to the county executive's post and to recapture the Legislature. Two years ago, the Democrats won a one-vote legislative majority, their first in decades, because of public outrage over mismanagement and soaring deficits.

docs.lead_paragraph: The UnitedHealth Group, a managed health care company, said yesterday that its third-quarter profits rose 27 percent, benefiting from higher insurance premiums in the face of rising medical costs. In the third quarter, UnitedHealth said its net income rose to $231 million, or 71 cents a share, from $182 million, or 54 cents a share, a year earlier. Analysts had expected 69 cents to 71 cents, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. Third-quarter operating profits were helped by strong growth in fee-based services, like managing drug trials for big pharmaceutical companies and administering health benefit plans for large employers.

docs.lead_paragraph: The rush to develop new vaccines and drugs to counter bioterrorism will pose another challenge: How should such drugs be tested so they can be approved for use? Normally, experimental drugs for diseases like cancer or arthritis are tested in clinical trials on people with the disease to see if the drugs are safe and effective. But there is no large group of people suffering from diseases like smallpox and anthrax, which are caused by pathogens that might be used by bioterrorists. And deliberately exposing people to lethal agents would be unethical.

headline.main: Rush for New Drugs Raises Questions About Testing

docs.abstract: Rush to develop new vaccines and drugs to counter bioterrorism will pose challenge of how should such drugs be tested so they can be approved for use; normally, experimental drugs are tested in clinical trials on people with disease to see if drugs are safe and effective, but there is no large group of people suffering from diseases like smallpox and anthrax, which are caused by pathogens that might be used by bioterrorists; deliberately exposing people to lethal agents would be unethical; Dr Jane E Henney, former commissioner of Food and Drug Administration, comments; FDA is rushing to put into effect rule first proposed in late 1999 that would allow data from animal studies to be used in place of human testing when it is impossible or unethical to do tests on patients (M)
